conclusion: Objects A and B are released above two cloth-covered platforms.
Gravity produces a downward acceleration on each object.
Object A heads toward the left platform where the support blocks are C (blue, shorter) and D (purple, taller).
Object B heads toward the right platform where the supports are E (dark, shorter) and F (red, taller).

premise: The cloth sags only until it meets the tallest block in each group.
conclusion: Object A touches the upper face of block D first, while Object B touches the upper face of block F first.

premise: At the instant of contact, the upward normal force supplied by the touched block(s) grows until it equals the weight of the falling object.
conclusion: The downward acceleration of A and B is brought to zero; any very small bounce is quickly damped by friction and the cloth.

premise: Object A ends up resting on the left-hand support (mainly on D, perhaps also lightly on C if the cloth is slack). Object B ends up resting on the right-hand support (mainly on F, perhaps also lightly on E).
conclusion: All motion stops: gravity is now balanced by the normal forces of the blocks, and the system is static.

premise: Objects A and B simply fall until the cloth lets them touch the tallest blocks beneath (D on the left, F on the right). After a brief deceleration they come to rest on those blocks; nothing else occurs.
conclusion: Both Object A and Object B are supported by the objects C, D, E, and F. Objects C, D, E, and F have not fallen down.
